importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the news report indicates the most recent update on the flood casualties and recovery efforts, highlighting the ongoing impact and response as of late October 2025.
The date corresponds to the official announcement of the rising death toll and missing persons, showing the current state of the crisis and the timeline of governmental response.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The flooding and related deaths occurred over a short period, emphasizing the sudden and severe nature of the disaster, which overwhelmed local infrastructure and emergency systems.
The heaviest rainfall was recorded on Wednesday in Veracruz and Puebla, marking the peak of the disaster and the worst conditions that led to fatalities and landslides.

keyTakeAways: At least 64 people have died in Mexico due to severe flooding across five states caused by heavy rains from the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond.
The National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC) chief, Laura Velazquez Alzua, reported that 65 people remain missing, with the highest numbers in Hidalgo (43), Veracruz (18), and Puebla (4).
Veracruz reported 29 deaths, Hidalgo 21, Puebla 13, and Queretaro one death.
Over 100,000 houses have been affected, with some properties near rivers reportedly 'practically disappeared'.
More than 80% of electricity supply has been restored across the five states, with around 263,000 users losing power initially.
The Mexican Army, Air Force, and National Guard have jointly deployed to deliver food, clean water, and emergency supplies through difficult access routes.
The government acknowledged a lack of early meteorological warnings, with President Claudia Sheinbaum stating there were no signs indicating the extreme rainfall magnitude.
Heavy rainfall reached 280mm in Cerro Azul (Veracruz) and 286mm in Cuetzalan del Progreso (Puebla), contributing directly to the flooding and landslides.
Governors are coordinating relief efforts, and thousands of military troops are deployed to assist in affected areas.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Severe flooding in Mexico, primarily affecting five states—Veracruz, Hidalgo, Puebla, and Queretaro—has resulted in at least 64 deaths and 65 people still missing. The disaster was triggered by heavy rainfall from the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, with the heaviest rains recorded in Cerro Azul (280mm) and Cuetzalan del Progreso (286mm). The National Civil Protection Coordination, led by Chief Laura Velazquez Alzua, reported the death and missing tolls, while President Claudia Sheinbaum highlighted the lack of early warning signs and the scale of response. Thousands of military personnel, including the Army, Air Force, and National Guard, have been deployed to deliver essential supplies, and over 80% of electricity supply has been restored across the affected regions. Approximately 100,000 homes were damaged, with some near rivers destroyed, indicating a major environmental and humanitarian crisis.
title: Mexico flooding death toll rises to 64, with dozens still missing
